description: Comprehensive Information Systems Security - Access Control, Attacks, Management & Application Security

questions.question: ......... are security features that control how users and systems communicate and interact with other systems and resources.

questions.question: What are the elements of the CIA Triad?

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason why using passwords alone is a poor security mechanism?
options: When possible, users choose easy-to-remember passwords, which are therefore easy to guess or crack.
Randomly generated passwords are hard to remember, thus many users write them down.
Short passwords can be discovered quickly in brute force attacks only when used against a stolen password database file.
Passwords can be stolen through many means, including observation, recording and playback, and security database theft.
questions.explanation: A brute force attack involves systematically trying every possible combination of credentials to guess a password. Passwords are the most common authentication mechanism but are also the weakest if not properly managed (complexity, length, rotation).

questions.question: In general how many key elements constitute the entire security structure?
questions.explanation: Explanation: The 4 key elements that constitute the security are: confidentiality, integrity, authenticity & availability. Authenticity is not considered as one of the key elements in some other security models, but the popular CIA Triad eliminates this as authenticity at times comes under confidentiality & availability.

questions.question: When you use the word _____ it means you are protecting your data from getting disclosed.
questions.explanation: Confidentiality ensures that information is not disclosed to unauthorized individuals, programs, or processes. It's one of the three pillars of the CIA triad. Confidential classification is used for data between Secret and Sensitive but Unclassified levels.

questions.question: ______ means the protection of data from modification by unknown users.
questions.explanation: Integrity ensures that data has not been altered or tampered with by unauthorized parties. It maintains the accuracy and consistency of data.

questions.question: _______ of information means, only authorised users are capable of accessing the information.
questions.explanation: Availability ensures that systems and data are accessible to authorized users when needed. It's critical for business continuity.

questions.question: Why these 4 elements (confidentiality, integrity, authenticity & availability) are considered fundamental?
options: They are key elements to a security breach
They help understands security and its components better
They help to understand the cyber-crime better
questions.explanation: Confidentiality ensures that information is not disclosed to unauthorized individuals, programs, or processes. It's one of the three pillars of the CIA triad. Integrity ensures that data has not been altered or tampered with by unauthorized parties. It maintains the accuracy and consistency of data.

questions.explanation: Access controls restrict access to resources based on the identity and privileges of users, protecting confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Discretionary Access Control (DAC) allows the owner of a resource to control who can access it.

questions.explanation: Access controls restrict access to resources based on the identity and privileges of users, protecting confidentiality, integrity, and availability. A subject is an active entity (user, process, or program) that requests access to an object or resource.

questions.explanation: Access controls restrict access to resources based on the identity and privileges of users, protecting confidentiality, integrity, and availability.

questions.explanation: Biometrics use unique physiological or behavioral characteristics (fingerprint, iris, voice, etc.) for identification or authentication. Fingerprints are unique patterns on fingertips used for biometric authentication, though affected by temperature, pressure, and surface damage.

questions.explanation: Access controls restrict access to resources based on the identity and privileges of users, protecting confidentiality, integrity, and availability. A subject is an active entity (user, process, or program) that requests access to an object or resource.

questions.explanation: Identification is the process of claiming an identity, typically through a username or ID. It's the first step before authentication.

questions.explanation: Accountability ensures that actions can be traced back to specific users or entities, typically through logging and audit trails.

questions.question: Controls to keep password sniffing attacks from compromising computer systems include which of the following?
questions.explanation: Passwords are the most common authentication mechanism but are also the weakest if not properly managed (complexity, length, rotation). One-time passwords (OTP) are valid for only a single login session or transaction, providing the strongest password-based security.

questions.question: What is the main concern with single sign-on?
options: Maximum unauthorized access would be possible if a password is disclosed.
The security administrator's workload would increase.
The users' password would be too hard to remember.
User access rights would be increased.
questions.explanation: Single Sign-On (SSO) allows a user to authenticate once and access multiple systems without re-authenticating, improving user experience but creating a single point of failure. Passwords are the most common authentication mechanism but are also the weakest if not properly managed (complexity, length, rotation).

questions.question: Which of the following is typically not used as an identification factor?

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a deterrent access control?
questions.explanation: Access controls restrict access to resources based on the identity and privileges of users, protecting confidentiality, integrity, and availability.

questions.question: Why is separation of duties important for security purposes?
options: It ensures that multiple people can do the same job.
It prevents an organization from losing important information when they lose important people.
It prevents any single security subject (person) from being able to make major security changes without involving other subjects.
It helps subjects concentrate their talents where they will be most useful.
questions.explanation: A subject is an active entity (user, process, or program) that requests access to an object or resource. Separation of duties prevents any single person from having complete control over critical processes, reducing fraud and errors.

A) Rainbow table B) Account lockout C) Salting passwords D) Encryption of password 58.What can be used as an authentication factor that is a behavioral or physiological characteristic unique to a subject? A) Account ID B) Biometric factor C) Token D) PIV 59.Which of the following is considered a primary goal of access control? A) Preserve confidentiality, integrity, and availability of systems. B) Ensure that only valid objects can authenticate on a system. C) Prevent unauthorized access to subjects. D) Ensure that all subjects are authenticated. 60.Users are given a device that generates one-time passwords every 60 seconds. A server hosted within the organization knows what this password is at any given time. What type of device is this? A) Synchronous token B) Asynchronous token C) Smart card D) Common access card 61.A biometric system has falsely rejected a valid user, indicating that the user is not recognized. What type of error is this? A) Type 1 error B) Type 2 error C) Crossover error rate D) Equal error rate 62.What is an access control list (ACL) based on? A) An object B) A subject C) A role D) An account 63.Which of the following is not used to support single sign-on? A) Kerberos B) Federated identity management system C) TACACS D) SPML 64.Single Sign-on (SSO) is characterized by which of the following advantages? A. Convenience B. Convenience and centralized administration C. Convenience and centralized data administration D. Convenience and centralized network administration

questions.question: Which of the following is not a valid measure to take to improve protection against brute force and dictionary attacks?
options: Enforce strong passwords through a security policy.
Maintain strict control over physical access.
Require all users to log in remotely.
questions.explanation: A brute force attack involves systematically trying every possible combination of credentials to guess a password. A dictionary attack uses a list of common passwords and words to attempt to guess user credentials.

questions.question: Spoofing is primarily used to perform what activity?
options: Send large amounts of data to a victim.
Hide the identity of an attacker through misdirection.
questions.explanation: Spoofing involves hiding the attacker's identity by using fake source addresses or credentials.

questions.question: Due diligence in security refers to:
options: Investigating and understanding security requirements before implementation
questions.explanation: Due diligence involves thoroughly investigating and understanding security requirements, risks, and best practices before implementing security measures.

questions.question: Due care in security means:
options: Taking reasonable steps to protect assets based on due diligence findings
questions.explanation: Due care involves taking reasonable and prudent actions to protect organizational assets based on what was learned through due diligence.

questions.question: Ransomware is malware that:
options: Encrypts files and demands payment for decryption
questions.explanation: Ransomware encrypts victim files or locks systems and demands payment (ransom) for the decryption key or unlock code.

questions.question: PKI (Public Key Infrastructure) provides:
options: Framework for managing digital certificates and public-key encryption
questions.explanation: PKI is a framework that manages digital certificates, public/private key pairs, and certificate authorities to enable secure communications and authentication.

questions.question: is a mechanism used to disable a user account after a specified number of failed logons.
questions.explanation: Account lockout automatically disables an account after a specified number of failed login attempts, preventing brute force attacks.

questions.question: Account lockouts stop brute-force and dictionary attacks against a system‚Äôs logon prompt.
questions.explanation: A dictionary attack uses a list of common passwords and words to attempt to guess user credentials. Account lockout automatically disables an account after a specified number of failed login attempts, preventing brute force attacks.

questions.explanation: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) monitor network or system activities for malicious activities or policy violations. Host-based IDS monitors a single system for suspicious activities, examining system logs and file changes.

questions.explanation: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) monitor network or system activities for malicious activities or policy violations.

questions.question: Which type of IDS can be considered an expert system?
questions.explanation: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) monitor network or system activities for malicious activities or policy violations.

questions.question: Which of the following is a fake network designed to tempt intruders with unpatched and unprotected security vulnerabilities and false data?
questions.explanation: A honey pot is a decoy system designed to attract and trap attackers, allowing security teams to study attack methods.

questions.question: When a padded cell is used by a network for protection from intruders, which of the following is true?
options: The data offered by the padded cell is what originally attracts the attacker.
Padded cells are a form of entrapment.
The intruder is seamlessly transitioned into the padded cell once they are detected.
Padded cells are used to test a system for known vulnerabilities.
questions.explanation: . Explanation: When an intruder is detected by an IDS, they are transferred to a padded cell. The transfer of the intruder into a padded cell is performed automatically, without informing the intruder that the change has occurred. The padded cell is unknown to the intruder before the attack, so it cannot serve as an enticement or entrapment. Padded cells are used to detain intruders, not to detect vulnerabilities.

questions.question: When using penetration testing to verify the strength of your security policy, which of the following is not recommended?
options: Mimicking attacks previously perpetrated against your system
Performing the attacks without managements consent
Using manual and automated attack tools
Reconfiguring the system to resolve any discovered vulnerabilities
questions.explanation: Penetration testing simulates attacks to identify vulnerabilities in systems, always requiring management consent.

questions.question: Which of the following attacks is an attempt to test every possible combination against a security feature in order to bypass it?
questions.explanation: A brute force attack involves systematically trying every possible combination of credentials to guess a password.

questions.question: A SYN flood attack works by what mechanism?

Using an amplification network to flood a victim with packets
Exploiting the three-way handshake used by TCP/IP
Sending oversized ping packets to a victim
questions.explanation: SYN flood attacks exploit the TCP three-way handshake by sending numerous SYN packets without completing the connection.

questions.question: A replay attack involves:
options: Capturing and retransmitting valid data to gain unauthorized access
questions.explanation: Replay attacks capture legitimate network traffic (like authentication credentials) and retransmit it later to gain unauthorized access. Kerberos prevents this using timestamps and tickets.

questions.question: Session hijacking is an attack where:
options: An attacker takes over an active session between two parties
An attacker creates a new session
An attacker monitors session data only
questions.explanation: Session hijacking involves an attacker taking control of an active authenticated session, allowing them to impersonate the legitimate user.

questions.question: A security baseline is:
options: A minimum level of security that all systems must meet
The bottom of a security fence
questions.explanation: A security baseline defines the minimum security standards and configurations that all systems in an organization must meet.

questions.question: Input validation is important to prevent:
questions.explanation: Input validation checks and sanitizes user input to prevent injection attacks (SQL, XSS, command injection) and buffer overflows by rejecting malicious or malformed data.

When a user is prompted for a username andpassword to use a computer, this is access control

questions.question: involve a user account accumulating privileges over time as job roles and assigned tasks change
questions.explanation: Creeping privilege occurs when user accounts accumulate excessive privileges over time as roles change.

questions.question: is accomplished by assigning privileges based on written policies that don‚Äôt change often
questions.explanation: One-time passwords or single-use passwordsare avariant ofdynamicpasswords that change every time theyare used

questions.question: is used when security requirements cannot be determined until the system is active and functioning.
questions.explanation: When you look upinformation in a database, you are the active subject and thedatabase is the passive object

questions.question: What are the two common data classification schemes?
questions.explanation: Data classification organizes data into categories based on sensitivity level (e.g., Top Secret, Secret, Confidential, Public).

questions.question: Which of the following is the lowest military data classification for classified data?
questions.explanation: Data classification organizes data into categories based on sensitivity level (e.g., Top Secret, Secret, Confidential, Public). Secret classification is used for data that could cause serious damage to national security if disclosed.

questions.question: Which commercial business/private sector data classification is used to control information about individuals within an organization?
questions.explanation: Data classification organizes data into categories based on sensitivity level (e.g., Top Secret, Secret, Confidential, Public).

questions.question: Data classifications are used to focus security controls over all but which of the following?
questions.explanation: Layering (defense in depth) uses multiple security controls at different levels to provide comprehensive protection. Data classification organizes data into categories based on sensitivity level (e.g., Top Secret, Secret, Confidential, Public).

questions.question: Risk assessment involves:
options: Identifying threats, vulnerabilities, and calculating potential impact
questions.explanation: Risk assessment is the process of identifying assets, threats, and vulnerabilities, then calculating the likelihood and potential impact to determine risk levels.

questions.question: A covert channel is:
options: An unauthorized communication path that violates security policy
questions.explanation: A covert channel is an unauthorized communication path that allows information transfer in ways not intended by the system designers, violating security policies.

questions.question: Data ___________ is used to ensure confidentiality.
questions.explanation: Confidentiality ensures that information is not disclosed to unauthorized individuals, programs, or processes. It's one of the three pillars of the CIA triad. Encryption transforms plaintext into unreadable ciphertext to protect confidentiality during storage or transmission.

questions.question: The process of transforming plain text into unreadable text.
questions.explanation: Encryption transforms plaintext into unreadable ciphertext to protect confidentiality during storage or transmission.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics can be used to differentiate worms from viruses?
options: Worms infect a system by overwriting data in the master boot record of a storage device.
Worms always spread from system to system without user intervention.
Worms always carry a malicious payload that impacts infected systems.
questions.explanation: 4.A media player that is running within a web browser is known as a(n): a. Agent b. Mashup c. Applet d. Script 5.Web beacons are an effective site usage tracker because: a. They use hidden form variables b. Browsers do not block and detect them c. They are encrypted

questions.question: The primary purpose for decreasing user privilege levels is:
options: To limit the effects of malware
questions.explanation: Excessive privilegeis when a user has more access, privilege, orpermission than their assigned work tasks dictate

questions.question: System hardening involves:
options: Removing unnecessary services and applying security configurations
questions.explanation: System hardening is the process of securing a system by reducing its attack surface through removing unnecessary services, closing ports, and applying secure configurations.
